reviewText: Blind Menace (1960) is a Theatrical episode of Master Sugar noichi, a vile blind man who wanders though 1621 Japan as a court masseur. He is a gambler, hard drinker, and con-artist but he defends only himself, suffering oppression and yet looking for power. Shintaro Katsu breathes life into his Sugar noichi character to help himself out in life.Of course, seeing the wonderful Shintaro Katsu in a blindswordsman Zatoichi -like but morally despicable part (he's an extortionist, murderer and rapist), is also great fun.
Title: N/A

reviewText: While I enjoyed the film, I just wanted to point out to others, that while it's got the same actor playing a similar looking blind masseuse... without the cane sword of course, he's not the lovable guy trying to make it in the world as in the Zatoichi films... he's a rapist, murderer and extortionist. It was kind of disturbing to watch "an old friend" act like that.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This movie dramatically tells a story of scheming, in-fighting and backstabbing for rank and favor in Japan's byzantine medieval social world.It has plenty of drama, blood, and male/female relations (can't say love),  and excitement, and provides an interesting window onto the class structure of old Japan, moreso than other famous "jidaigeki" (period pieces).(Some background):  In old Japan people were divided into social classes they were born into, and could only very rarely get out of.  Generally it is said there were 4 classes (farmers, craftsmen, merchants, samurai) but there were others, royalty, untouchables, foreigners, and the blind and deaf among them.  This is the story of a blind man fighting within the blind branch of society for a high position, called kengyo.  The Jpns title is "Shiranui Kengyo" with Shiranui being a person's name).  The blind were restricted to the occupations of masseuse or musician.  ,(For anyone who plays shakuhachi or koto or another jpns instrument, and were wondering who all those "so-and-so Kengyo" composers of classical music were, here is one insight into the answer, although this movie is about a kengyo who is a masseuse).  Well I have written more about the social milieu than the movie, but it is a fascinating world, and one which still reverberates throughout Jpns society still today (lifelong employment, loyalty to group/company, etc.  The dark tale that is Blind Menace is also quite fascinating and well done.  Shintaro Katsu does a great job as always.
summary: Good story, interesting look at Japan's medieval set-in-stone social classes

reviewText: Before any of the Zatoichi series was filmed or conceived, this was a character Shintaro Katsu (the actor who went on to play Zatoichi) acted out -- a cunning, amoral, and greedy schemer who is able to rise to the top through his evil deeds.  He did so well on this he and others developed the character later into the good manifestation of this same clever character.  I love the Zatoichi series, and have watched a good portion of them, and so this character came as a bit of a shock.  But if you pay close attention to the structure of samurai movies, this is the samurai equivalent of a tragedy, if not horror story: someone who so subverts the relationships held sacred in society -- master and pupil, servant and noble, and even husband and wife -- is able to cruelly upend and destroy the order of things to further his selfish agenda.  Unlike its Western counterparts, there is no noble aspect to Suginoichi. The end is a dark catharsis of the betrayals and destruction Suginoichi has left behind.Definitely recommended, and I think especially for Zatoichi fans, because it gives one an insight into what Zatoichi might have become, as well as an appreciation for his restraint in situations he might have taken advantage of.  As always the DVD production is fantastic, with characteristic Animeigo historical notes, subtitles differentiated for characters by different colors, and a very nice image for a 1960 film.  I hesitated both before buying the film and watching it, but I'm glad now I took the plunge on both!

reviewText: ZATOICHI AS A ROGUE? UNBELIEVEABLE! Along with being such a surprise, the episode is extremely well done, very realistically conveyed with a body count that's both less and more (less is more?) than any other episodes (I have'em all now). A collector's item for sure, rare, bizarreand raw. For fans, a very-much must-have.
summary: A TOTALLY UNEXPECTED TAKE ON THE LEGENDARY BLIND YAKUZA MASSUSE!

reviewText: I love Zatoichi, both the movies and the tv shows,This version also included cultural remarks which was nice and the movie was terrific. Shintaro Katsu and all the actors were terrific and my wife and I agreed this was definitely a great prequel to Zatoichi. It starts out as the young by who becomes a man who just a nasty piece of work. You don't get the flash of action like in Zatoichi, but you definitely get the drama and intensity of a good story.Glad we added this to our collection.

reviewText: The blind masseur Sugino-ichi is just like the blind masseur Zato-ichi, with a subtle difference.  While both roles are played by legendary actor Katsu Shintaro, when Zatoichi comes upon a woman in need, he immediately sets forth on a crusade to lift her from her plight with no thought of reward for himself.  When Suginoichi comes upon a woman in need, however, he rapes her and the discards her into the street, maybe have a chuckle later when he hears how the woman killed herself, saying that it wasn't such a big deal she needed to die over it."Blind Menace" (Japanese title: "Shiranui kengyo") is the evil twin of the long-running "Zatoichi" series.  The film could almost be seen as some sort of twisted parody of Zatoichi were it not for the fact that "Blind Menace" pre-dates the first "Zatoichi" film by two years.  It makes you wonder what director or producer saw Katsu in this film and thought "he does that blind bit really good but maybe if the character was a kind vagrant wanderer rather than a rapist and a murderer we might have something here..."From the opening scenes of "Blind Menace," we see that Suginoichi was just born bad.  He spends his childhood using his blindness to scam people out of money, and he doesn't grow up any better.  As a student of the Shiranui Kengyo (Kengyo being the highest official rank of blind masseur, able to work on the shogun and royal family, the descending ranks being betto", "koto", and "zato."), Suginoichi would still rather get ahead by graft than by craft.  He has set his sights on assuming the Kengyo's rank and position, but would rather have it now rather than suffer through the years required to earn the position.  When one of Suginoichi's casual murders is overseen by career criminal who goes by the name "Severed Head," an uneasy partnership is forged between the two as Suginoichi uses his massage clients to glean private secrets that Severed Head and his gang can take advantage of.  Suginoichi's greed is not contained by petty evils, however, and he plots to murder the current Kengyo, his master, something which even Severed Head balks at.Although "Blind Menace" is going to constantly be compared to Zatoichi (and justifiably so, as Katsu clearly used the same mannerisms, facial expressions and style of movement to portray both blind characters) it does stand on its own as a dark and interesting film with a villain as its protagonist.  Suginoichi is truly a despicable character, who performs some vile scams that managed to shock me more than fifty years after its release.  There is one scene in particular that I don't want to spoil, but it is a rare gem of villainy that Suginoichi concocts.Director Mori Kazuo would go on to direct a few entries in the Zatoichi series, including theThe Tale of Zatoichi ContinuesandZatoichi at Large, one of the most acclaimed Zatoichi films.  He does good work here in "Blind Menace," managing to keep the tone light when Suginoichi is doing his charming best and then suddenly shift to a darker tone as Suginoichi's true face is revealed."Zatoichi" fans might be a little shocked with "Blind Menace" do to the sexual violence and despicable nature of the usually loveable Katsu Shintaro.  However, anyone who has seen Katsu's other films, like theHanzo the Razorseries that Katsu produced himself, will be less shocked at seeing Katsu in this kind of role.Animeigo has put together a solid release of "Blind Menace," along with their usual fantastic job with the subtitles (really, the do the best Japanese subtitling in the business) along with program notes, a trailer and cast and crew biographies.
Title: N/A
